Description: Fragment of tridacna species clam shell with incised and decoration. Used as a dish. Incised with floral motifs including lotus flowers and buds. Traces of paint may be preserved within incisions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Brandl 2001, the production of carved tridacna shells was located in the Levantine (Syro-Palestinian) region and confined to the period of ca. 630-580BC. Brandl, B. 2001, 'Two Engraved Tridacna Shells from Tel Miqne-Ekron', Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research, 323, pp. 49-62.
Bibliographic references: Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 49, fig. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WA.08)
